I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help operationalize Uzbekistan 
Mortgage Refinancing Company (UMRC), which is to provide long-term funding to the banks in 
Uzbekistan to stimulate market-based mortgage financing.1 This will allow Uzbekistan to gradually 
develop its finance sector and capital markets, and will contribute to the country’s long-term 
sustainable growth. 
 
2.  This TA will build on the outputs of the TA for the Mortgage Market Development Program, 
which produced the business plan for UMRC, including a road map for the operationalization of 
the company and an outline of the regulatory changes required to ensure market uptake.2 The 
proposed TA will be a natural continuation of these efforts by financing advisory services to 
support the actual establishment of the company—advising on the legal structure, capitalization, 
and staffing requirements; and preparing operational documents such as the lending policy, risk 
manual, and human resources policy. 
 
3.  The TA is an additional request to the Country Operations Business Plan (2019–2021).3 
The TA outputs will serve as a direct input to the realization of Output 3 of the Mortgage Market 
Sector Development Program (MMSDP) under preparation, namely to establish the UMRC.4  
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The steady growth of Uzbekistan’s population is putting substantial pressure on the 
economy to supply sufficient and adequate housing. While the government is trying to meet some 
of the key challenges on the supply side of the housing market, especially in the rural areas, with 
the assistance of international donors, notably the Asian Development Bank (ADB), its fiscal 
resources are not sufficient. To supplement these resources, market-based mortgage financing 
needs to be mobilized through commercial banking. However, the market-based residential 
mortgage loan market in Uzbekistan is severely underdeveloped. The ratio of mortgage loans to 
gross domestic product is only 4.8% (compared with close to 50.0% in developed countries) and 
the total mortgage loan portfolio is only 14.2% of the banks’ total loan portfolio in Uzbekistan 
(while it was about 24.5% in Armenia, 41.7% in Russia, or 41.6% in the United States in 2016).5 
 
5.  The lack of access to long-term funding sources is one of the main reasons commercial 
banks have been unable to play their financial intermediation role in housing finance. To rectify 
this issue, ADB is working with the Government of Uzbekistan on the MMSDP. Under the MMSDP, 
ADB is proposing to provide up to $200 million to support the development of the mortgage market 
in the country.6 
 
6.  MMSDP will have three outputs: (i) bridge the gaps in the housing policy and subsidy 
environment to reduce the reliance on various government-sponsored housing programs that are 
mostly inefficient, untargeted, and expensive, and simultaneously start the development of the

6  The proposed ADB assistance will include a policy-based loan to support the proposed changes in the housing policy

2 
commercial  mortgage  finance  industry  through  policy-based  actions;  (ii)  strengthen  the 
management, monitoring, evaluation, and design of Uzbekistan’s present and new housing 
programs through the setup of a housing assistance unit under the auspices of the Ministry of 
Finance; and (iii) establish UMRC, which will directly address the lack of long-term funding to the 
banking subsector by raising long-term finance—first from donors such as ADB, and at a later 
stage through the domestic capital markets. 
 
7.  UMRC will be a dedicated wholesale mortgage refinance institution to be established as 
a  joint  venture  between  the  government  and  Uzbek  banking.  The  company  will  be  run 
commercially and will offer long-term funding on market-based terms to all participating financial 
institutions (PFIs). At the same time, it will promote technical competence inside the housing 
finance segment; encourage competition in banking; collect data and information; and build 
capacity for and awareness of the importance of a well-developed housing finance industry 
among banks, regulators, market practitioners, and the public.  
 
8.  UMRC will serve as a secure source of long-term funding to all PFIs at attractive rates 
while ensuring sound lending practices and introducing harmonized lending standards among 
PFIs.7 This will help reduce the maturity mismatch risk for the PFIs, increase the availability of 
fixed interest rate mortgages, and ultimately improve the terms and pricing of mortgage loans. In 
turn, this will help improve the affordability of mortgages and increase the number of qualifying 
borrowers, and result in the expansion of the primary mortgage market. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: access to market-based mortgage finance for 
lower- and middle-income households improved.8 The TA will have the following outcome: the 
UMRC is operational.9 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output  1:  Institutional  structure  of  UMRC  established.  The  operational  and 
institutional structure of UMRC are drafted and a workable regulatory and supervisory framework 
based on international good practices on which UMRC can operate successfully is adopted.  
 
11.  Output  2:  UMRC’s  operational  framework  developed.  Constitutive  documents, 
strategy, systems, and corresponding operational policies and manuals will be adopted and 
developed. This will include the development of standard documentation for UMRC on various 
product offerings (based on a thorough market assessment), assessment of the safeguards 
management systems of participating financial institutions, preparation of an environmental and 
social monitoring framework for UMRC and a safeguard screening checklist for the participating 
financial institutions. 
 
12.  Output 3: Information and communication technology support established. The use 
of information and communication technology will be critical in the preparation of a comprehensive 
                                                
7  UMRC will provide incentives to PFIs to apply sound lending practices and harmonized lending standards so as to 
qualify for its lending. UMRC will refinance mortgage loans that are originated under eligibility criteria or minimum 
quality standards (based on international best practices and domestic regulation). 
8  Consistent with the Government of Uzbekistan’s National Development Strategy for 2017–2021. 
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
management  information  system  for  UMRC.  This  will  assist  in  developing  proper  and 
standardized underwriting standards and procedures for mortgage lending in the country. UMRC 
will establish an information and communication technology platform as a central data repository 
to collect, in consolidated form, statistical information on the housing finance market. This can 
then be analyzed and shared with directly concerned stakeholders (Government of Uzbekistan, 
Central Bank and Banker’s Association) and the public. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and administered by ADB. The 
cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
14.  Proceeds from the fund will support the operationalization of UMRC by finalizing its 
operational road map and business plan, and preparing the core policies, manuals, and systems, 
including the establishment of an environmental and social monitoring framework. The following 
are ineligible expenditures under the fund: (i) civil works, (ii) procurement of large-scale equipment, 
and (iii) permanent staffing cost or hiring of staff consultants. 
 
15.  The government will provide support in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, 
interdepartmental coordination, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB, through its Central and West Asia Department, will 
implement the TA with support from the Uzbekistan Resident Mission.

18.  Consulting services.  ADB will engage a consulting firm following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions

4 
and/or staff instructions.10 ADB will engage the consulting firm through the quality-based selection 
method with simplified technical proposal procedure. The estimated consultant input comprises 
of 12.5 person-months of international, and 13.5 person-months of national, consulting services; 
the proposing entities may propose some adjustments  with justification. Depending on the 
emerging circumstances, the CWRD team implementing the TA will retain flexibility on the number 
and person-month allocations among the experts as well as their tasks. 
 
19.  The quality of the downstream lending activities of the UMRC and the development of the 
housing finance market in the country is contingent on the sound development of this institution. 
It is therefore important that the constitutive documents, strategy, systems, and policies of UMRC 
are developed in line with international best practices. 
 
20.  Cofinancier requirements. The Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership 
Fund requires an annual progress report to be submitted within the first month after the end of 
each calendar year. The TA team will prepare a TA completion report within a year after the TA 
closing date.    
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 
to the Government of Uzbekistan to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia 
and Knowledge Partnership Fund for Operationalization of the Uzbekistan Mortgage Refinancing 
Company, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
